content.description: A bank manager wants the average time that a customer waits in line to be at most 3 minutes. Customers at the bank have complained about the long wait times. To test whether the average wait time at the bank is greater than 3 minutes, 60 customers were randomly selected as they entered the bank and their wait times were recorded. The mean wait time was 4.7 minutes. A one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test resulted in a <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of 0.00031.
content.question: Which of the following is an appropriate interpretation of the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value?

choices.label: The probability that the population mean wait time is greater than 3 minutes is 0.00031.
The probability that the sample mean wait time is greater than 3 minutes is 0.00031.
If the population mean wait time is greater than 3 minutes, the probability of observing a sample mean wait time of 4.7 minutes or more is 0.00031.
If the population mean wait time is 3 minutes, the probability of observing a sample mean wait time of 4.7 minutes is 0.00031.
If the population mean wait time is 3 minutes, the probability of observing a sample mean wait time of 4.7 minutes or more is 0.00031.

content.answer: If the population mean wait time is 3 minutes, the probability of observing a sample mean wait time of 4.7 minutes or more is 0.00031.

topic.text: 7.5: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
